docs.title: Welcome to Biology Problems
docs.text: Explore free and open problem sets for Biochemistry, Genetics, and more! Click on a subject to get started.

docs.text:

docs.title: List of Biochemistry Topics
docs.text: Explore the foundational concepts and techniques in Biochemistry. Click on a topic to dive deeper.

docs.title: Topics
docs.text:
1. The Molecular Design of Life

    • Molecular design of life, major elements, and biomacromolecules.

  2. Water Chemistry and pH

    • Properties of water, pH, pKa, and buffering systems.

  3. Amino Acids

    • Amino acid structure, types, and roles in protein structure.

  4. Proteins: Structure and Folding

    • Protein folding, structural levels, and mechanisms.

  5. Protein Purification Techniques

    • Isolation and analysis methods, chromatography, electrophoresis.

  6. Enzymes Reactions and Thermodynamics

    • Enzyme functions, substrate binding, and energy changes in reactions.

  7. Enzyme Kinetics and Inhibition

    • Reaction rates, enzyme efficiency, and inhibition mechanisms.

  8. Ligand Binding, Allostery, and Regulation

    • Ligand binding, allosteric effects, and feedback regulation.

  9. Carbohydrates: Monosaccharides to Polysaccharides

    • Carbohydrate structure, glycosidic bonds, biological roles.

  10. Nucleic Acids: Structure and Applications

    • Nucleotide structure, DNA/RNA functions, biotechnology applications.

  11. Biochemistry of Human Senses

    • Taste, smell, hearing, sight, and touch.

docs.title: Topic 1: The Molecular Design of Life
docs.text: Molecular design of life, major elements, and biomacromolecules.

docs.title: Types of Macromolecules
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Types of Macromolecules example problem

ae5aWhich one of the following types of macromolecules correspond to the macromolecule 'serum albumin – family of water-soluble polypeptides found in blood plasma'.

  • A. carbohydrates
  • B. lipids
  • C. nucleic acids
  • D. proteins
Check Answer

docs.title: Hydrophobic Compounds from Molecular Formulas
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Hydrophobic Compounds from Molecular Formulas example problem

7371

Based on their molecular formula, which one of the following compounds is most likely hydrophobic?
  • A. ethylene, CH2CH2
  • B. phosphoric acid, H3PO4
  • C. methanol, CH3OH 
  • D. ethanol, CH3CH2OH 
  • E. glycine, NH2CH2COOH 
Check Answer

docs.title: Macromolecule Types Based on Chemical Structures
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Macromolecule Types Based on Chemical Structures example problem

4f9d

Guide to Identifying the Chemical Structures of Macromolecules Carbohydrates (monosaccharides)
  • Should have about the same number of oxygens as carbons.
  • Look for hydroxyl groups (–OH) attached to the carbon atoms.
  • Carbonyl groups (C=O) are often present as well.
  • Look for the base unit of CH2O.
  • Larger carbohydrates will form hexagon or pentagon ring-like structures.
Lipids (fatty acids)
  • Contain mostly carbon and hydrogen.
  • Very few oxygens and often no nitrogens.
  • Fats and oils will have carboxyl groups (–COOH) and ester bonds
  • Look for long chains or ring structures of only carbon and hydrogen.
  • Steroids have four interconnected carbon rings.
Proteins (amino acids and dipeptides)
  • Always have a nitrogen/amino group (–NH2 or –NH3+)
  • Always have a carboxyl group (–COOH or –COO-)
  • Identify the central Cα (alpha-carbon) attached to an amino group and a carboxyl group
  • Larger protein macromolecules will have a characteristic peptide bond (C–N)
  • Try to identify common side chains (R groups).
Nucleic acids (nucleobases)
  • Must have a nucleobase, rings containing carbon and nitrogen.
  • Larger nucleic acids will have a sugar backbone and phosphate groups.
Phosphate groups (–PO42-)
  • Found in all of the macromolecule types.
  • It is best to ignore them to not let them confuse you.
  • The breakdown of carbohydrates involves add phosphates.
  • Membrane lipids have phosphate head groups.
  • Many proteins are phosphorylated for regulatory purposes.
  • DNA has a phosphate backbone.

Molecule Information Full name Dioleoyl phosphatidylethanolamine Molecular formula C41 H78 NO8 P Molecular weight 744.00 g/mol Image link link to static image Partition coefficient 10.6 logP C/(O+N) ratio 6.8 Which one of the four main types of macromolecules is represented by the chemical structure of dioleoyl phosphatidylethanolamine shown above?
  • A. Carbohydrates (monosaccharides)
  • B. Lipids (fatty acids)
  • C. Proteins (amino acids and dipeptides)
  • D. Nucleic acids (nucleobases)
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 2: Water Chemistry and pH
docs.text: Properties of water, pH, pKa, and buffering systems.

docs.title: Correct Form of the Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Correct Form of the Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation example problem

345cWhich one of the following equations is the correct form of the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation?

  • A.

    pH = pKa + log10[A–][HA]

  • B.

    pH = pKa + log10[HA][A–]

Check Answer

docs.title: Optimal Buffering Range using pKa
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Optimal Buffering Range using pKa example problem

2be7Citric acid and its conjugate base, citrate, is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle.Citric acid is triprotic with pKa values of 3.13, 4.76, and 6.39.Which one of the following pH values falls outside the optimal buffering rangeof Citric acid?

  • A. pH 4.2
  • B. pH 5.5
  • C. pH 5.7
  • D. pH 7.0
  • E. pH 8.2
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Diprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Most Abundant Diprotic State at pH using pKa example problem

c9b3Uric acid and its conjugate base, urate, is an end product of nucleotide purine metabolism..Uric acid is diprotic with pKa values of 5.40 and 10.30.Uric acid has three possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 8.0?

  • A. C5H2N4O32-
  • B. C5H3N4O3-
  • C. C5H4N4O3
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Triprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Most Abundant Triprotic State at pH using pKa example problem

803fPhosphoric acid and its conjugate base, phosphate, is abbreviated Pi and is formed by cells from the hydrolysis of ATP into ADP.Phosphoric acid is triprotic with pKa values of 2.16, 7.21, and 12.32.Phosphoric acid has four possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 3.5?

  • A. H3PO4
  • B. H2PO4-
  • C. HPO42-
  • D. PO43-
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Tetraprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Most Abundant Tetraprotic State at pH using pKa example problem

8276Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid and its conjugate base, EDTA, is commonly used in chelation therapy and as a chelating agent in biochemical experiments..Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid is tetraprotic with pKa values of 2.00, 2.67, 6.16, and 10.26.Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid has five possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 8.0?

  • A. C10H12N2O84-
  • B. C10H13N2O83-
  • C. C10H14N2O82-
  • D. C10H15N2O8-
  • E. C10H16N2O8
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 3: Amino Acids
docs.text: Amino acid structure, types, and roles in protein structure.

docs.title: Determining Dipeptide Sequence from Structure
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Determining Dipeptide Sequence from Structure example problem

8d74

peptide_4529

A dipeptide is made up of two (2) amino acids. The figure above shows one such dipeptide with an unknown sequence. Your task is to find out the two (2) letter sequence of this dipeptide.Here is a step-by-step guide to help you answer the question:

  1. Consult an amino acid guide for reference. You can find a PDF guide on Blackboard under "Exam and Quiz" in the "Old Exams" section, with the filename bchm_exam-help_sheet.pdf, or search online for a visual guide that shows all 20 amino acids with their single-letter codes.
  2. Identify the amino-terminal end, represented as NH3+ and highlighted in bright green. Distinguish between the general nitrogens in amino acid backbones (denoted as NH) and the nitrogen in amino acid side chains.
  3. The one (1) peptide bonds connecting the two (2) amino acids are highlighted in bright green, making it easier to distinguish the two (2) amino acids.
  4. Examine the side chain for each of the two (2) amino acids to determine their single-letter amino acid code.
  5. List the single-letter amino acid codes in the amino to carboxyl (N→C) direction. This is the standard method for writing peptide sequences.

Select the correct peptide sequence from the options below:

  • A. QW 
  • B. FW 
  • C. MC 
  • D. QC 
  • E. YH 
Check Answer

  • B. glutamine
  • C. histidine
  • D. isoleucine
  • E. methionine

docs.title: Levels of Protein Structure
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Levels of Protein Structure example problem

e0f8Which one of the following levels of protein structure correspond to the description 'α-helix structures linked by backbone hydrogen bonding'.

  • A. primary
  • B. quaternary
  • C. secondary
  • D. tertiary
Check Answer

docs.title: Hydrogen Bonding in Alpha-Helix Structures
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Hydrogen Bonding in Alpha-Helix Structures example problem

4ca2The α-helix is a right-handed coil in which each backbone N–H group forms a hydrogen bond with the C=O group of an amino acid located a few residues away. The regular pattern of hydrogen bonding stabilizes the helix, preventing it from unraveling.In a long α-helix, amino acid number 6 would form a hydrogen bond with which two other amino acids?Select the correct pair of amino acids below.

  • A. amino acids 5 and 7 (a residue shift of 1 position) 
  • B. amino acids 4 and 8 (a residue shift of 2 positions) 
  • C. amino acids 3 and 9 (a residue shift of 3 positions) 
  • D. amino acids 2 and 10 (a residue shift of 4 positions) 
  • E. amino acids 1 and 11 (a residue shift of 5 positions) 
Check Answer

docs.title: Ionic Bond Formation in Amino Acid Side Chains
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Ionic Bond Formation in Amino Acid Side Chains example problem

c767

Based on the chemical properties of amino acid side chains, which pair of amino acids listed below can form an ionic bond between their side chains?
  • A. Glycine and Lysine 
  • B. Glycine and Serine 
  • C. Asparagine and Glutamate 
  • D. Glycine and Phenylalanine 
  • E. Aspartic Acid and Lysine 
Check Answer

docs.title: Determining Net Charge of Proteins at Given pH
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Determining Net Charge of Proteins at Given pH example problem

78d7

Isoelectric Point Problem Protein Name isoelectric point (pI) molecular weight Elastase II (Ela) 8.5 26.5

The protein in the table (above) is placed in a buffer solution with a pH of 7.5.What is the correct net charge on the Ela protein at pH of 7.5

?
  • A. The protein will have a net positive (+) charge. 
  • B. The protein will have a net negative (–) charge. 
  • C. The protein will have a net neutral (0) charge. 
Check Answer

docs.title: Protein Migration Direction Based on Isoelectric Point
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Protein Migration Direction Based on Isoelectric Point example problem

8843

Isoelectric Point Problem

A mixture of two proteins are to be separated by isoelectric focusing.

ProteinName IsoelectricPoint (pI) MolecularWeight Histone (His) 10.8 15.0 Insulin (Ins) 5.4 5.8

Both protein samples are placed into a gel with a constant pH of 8.0. The gel is then placed into an electric field.In which direction will each protein in the table migrate at pH 8.0?

  • A. Both His and Ins will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal 
  • B. Both His and Ins will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal 
  • C. His will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal Ins will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal 
  • D. His will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal Ins will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal 
Check Answer

docs.title: Estimating Protein Molecular Weight from SDS-PAGE Migration
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Estimating Protein Molecular Weight from SDS-PAGE Migration example problem

def8

Gel Migration Problem

In this task, data from an SDS-PAGE experiment, where proteins are separated based on molecular weight, is provided. The gel results table below shows some standard proteins with known molecular weights and one unknown protein.

Protein Name MolecularWeight (kDa) MigrationDistance (cm) Streptavidin (Stp) 13.2 3.44 Avidin (Av) 16.9 3.24 Succinate Ligase (SL) 20.9 3.07 Elastase II (Ela) 26.5 2.88 Tropomyosin (Trop) 35.0 2.66 Fumerase (Fum) 48.5 2.39 Fibrinogen (Fib) 63.5 2.18 Unknown ? 2.48 Estimate the molecular weight of the unknown protein by comparing its gel migration distance with those of the standards.
  • A. 15 kDa 
  • B. 19 kDa 
  • C. 23 kDa 
  • D. 30 kDa 
  • E. 44 kDa 
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 6: Enzymes Reactions and Thermodynamics
docs.text: Enzyme functions, substrate binding, and energy changes in reactions.

docs.title: Energy Terms and Their Categories
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Energy Terms and Their Categories example problem

9ba9Which one of the following energy requirement categories correspond to the energy term 'polymer breakdown'.

  • A. releases energy
  • B. requires energy input
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Chemical Reactions
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show True/False Statements on Chemical Reactions example problem

6eb8Which one of the following statements is FALSE regarding chemical reactions?

  • A. Chemical reactions play a role in many important biological processes. 
  • B. Chemical reactions always involve a change in the chemical composition of substances. 
  • C. Chemical reactions always result in a decrease in entropy. 
  • D. Chemical reactions always transform one or more substances into one or more different substances. 
  • E. Salt (NaCl) dissolving in water breaking the ionic bonds between Na+ and Cl– is a physical reaction. 
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG = ΔH - T ΔS)
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show True/False Statements on Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG = ΔH - T ΔS) example problem

5ec8Which one of the following statements is FALSE about the Gibbs free energy, ΔG = ΔH – TΔS?

  • A. When ΔH < 0 the reaction is called non-spontaneous
  • B. When ΔG = 0 the reaction has reached equilibrium 
  • C. entropy is associated with a state of disorder, randomness, or uncertainty 
  • D. ΔH is the change in enthalpy
  • E. Tis the temperature in degrees Kelvin
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Thermodynamics vs. Kinetics
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show True/False Statements on Thermodynamics vs. Kinetics example problem

c069Which one of the following statements is TRUE of thermodynamics and kinetics?

  • A. The rate of a reaction is independent of temperature. 
  • B. The first law of thermodynamics states that the total entropy of a closed system will always increase. 
  • C. Kinetics depends only on the concentration of reactants. 
  • D. Enzymes change the equilibrium point. 
  • E. Enzymes do NOT change the standard change in free energy (ΔG°′) of a reaction. 
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 7: Enzyme Kinetics and Inhibition
docs.text: Reaction rates, enzyme efficiency, and inhibition mechanisms.

docs.title: Enzyme Inhibition and Activation in Metabolic Pathways
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Enzyme Inhibition and Activation in Metabolic Pathways example problem

c553A series of enzymes catalyze the reactions in the following metabolic pathway:

enzyme 1 enzyme 2 enzyme 3 enzyme 4 H  ⟶  I  ⟶  J  ⟶  K  ⟶  L

Understanding the type of enzyme inhibition or activation is crucial for developing effective drugs and understanding metabolic regulation.

enzyme 1 converts substrate H into product I.

The end product L of this pathway binds to enzyme 1at a location far away from its active site.This binding decreases the activity of the enzyme.Determine the type of enzyme inhibition or activation described:

  • A. competitive inhibitor 
  • B. molecular stopper 
  • C. non-competitive inhibitor 
  • D. enzyme activator 
  • E. un-competitive inhibitor 
Check Answer

docs.title: Enzyme Catalysis Terminology
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Enzyme Catalysis Terminology example problem

83c7Which one of the following terms related to enzyme catalysis correspond to the definition 'any substance that is produced as a result of a chemical reaction'.

  • A. Coenzyme
  • B. Product
  • C. Substrate
  • D. Transition state
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Enzyme Kinetics
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show True/False Statements on Enzyme Kinetics example problem

ab15Which one of the following statements is FALSE regarding enzyme kinetics?

  • A. enzymes are needed in large quantities as they are used up in a chemical reaction 
  • B. enzymes cannot change the standard free energy (ΔG°′) of a chemical reaction 
  • C. enzymes cannot change the equilibrium of the chemical reaction 
  • D. enzymes increase the rate of a chemical reaction 
  • E. enzymes decrease the activation energy of a chemical reaction 
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Michaelis-Menten Kinetics
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show True/False Statements on Michaelis-Menten Kinetics example problem

1554Which one of the following statements is FALSE concerning Michaelis-Menten kinetics?

  • A. M-M kinetics assumes that there is no substrate available and there is no measureable reverse reaction rate. 
  • B. M-M kinetics was developed by German biochemist Leonor Michaelis and Canadian physician Maud Menten in 1913. 
  • C. When the substrate concentration, [S], is much larger than KM, the reaction rate is constant. 
  • D. The reaction rate is proportional to the substrate concentration. 
  • E. M-M kinetics does NOT apply to allosteric enzymes. 
Check Answer

docs.title: Which Molecule Cannot be an Enzyme Cofactors
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Which Molecule Cannot be an Enzyme Cofactors example problem

1528

Which one of the following molecular entities CANNOT be classified as an enzymatic cofactor?
  • A. nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP+ → NADPH) 
  • B. the organic molecule of a heme porphyrin with an iron ion, Fe2+, attached 
  • C. estradiol (E2), one of the estrogen steroid hormones responsible for female sex characteristics 
  • D. potassium ion, K+
  • E. insulin, a hormone and a protein 
Check Answer

docs.title: Michaelis-Menten Constant (K<sub>M</sub>) from Enzyme Activity Data
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Michaelis-Menten Constant (KM) from Enzyme Activity Data example problem

a532Michaelis-Menten question. The following question refers to the table (below) of enzyme activity.

substrateconcentration, [S] initial reactionvelocityV0 0.001  70.0  0.002  93.4  0.005  116.7  0.010  127.3  0.020  133.4  0.050  137.3  0.100  138.7  0.200  139.4  0.500  139.8  1.000  139.9  10.000  140.0 

Using the table (above), calculate the value for the Michaelis-Menten constant, KM.

  • A. KM = 0.001
  • B. KM = 0.002
  • C. KM = 0.005
  • D. KM = 0.020
  • E. KM = 0.050
Check Answer

docs.title: Inhibition Type Determination from Enzyme Activity Data
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Inhibition Type Determination from Enzyme Activity Data example problem

0b98Michaelis-Menten Kinetics and Inhibition Type DeterminationThe table below presents data on enzyme activity measured as initial reaction velocities (V0) with and without the presence of an inhibitor at various substrate concentrations ([S]).

substrateconcentration, [S] initial reactionvelocity no inhibitorV0 (–inh) initial reactionvelocity with inhibitorV0 (+inh) 0.0001  0.8  1.0  0.0002  1.6  1.9  0.0005  3.7  4.0  0.0010  6.7  6.7  0.0020  11.5  10.0  0.0050  20.0  14.3  0.0100  26.7  16.7  0.0200  32.0  18.2  0.0500  36.4  19.3  0.1000  38.1  19.7  1.0000  39.9  20.0  10.0000  40.0  20.0 

Based on the data provided, determine the type of inhibition show by the inhibitor. Consider how the addition of the inhibitor affects the initial reaction velocities (V0) at various substrate concentrations ([S]).

  • A. competitive 
  • B. intra-competitive 
  • C. non-competitive 
  • D. poly-competitive 
  • E. un-competitive 
Check Answer

docs.title: Which Molecule Could be an Enzyme
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Which Molecule Could be an Enzyme example problem

734fEnzymes are biological catalysts that speed up chemical reactions in living organisms.Which one of the following choices is most likely an enzyme?Hint: enzymes often have a distinct naming pattern that can help identify them.

  • A. cholesterol 
  • B. acetylcholinesterase 
  • C. GTP 
  • D. carbon dioxide (CO2) 
  • E. microtubules 
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 8: Ligand Binding, Allostery, and Regulation
docs.text: Ligand binding, allosteric effects, and feedback regulation.

docs.title: Allosteric Enzymes in Metabolic Pathways
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT Click to show Allosteric Enzymes in Metabolic Pathways example problem

5db5A series of enzymes catalyze the reactions in the following metabolic pathway:

enzyme 1 enzyme 2 enzyme 3 enzyme 4 enzyme 5 K  ⟶  L  ⟶  M  ⟶  N  ⟶  O  ⟶  P

In a typical metabolic pathway, an allosteric enzyme is sensitive to changes in concentration of specific molecules and can regulate the rate of reactions.Which one of the enzymes in the metabolic pathway above is most likely to be an allosteric enzyme?

  • A. enzyme 1 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate K to product L
  • B. enzyme 2 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate L to product M
  • C. enzyme 3 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate M to product N
  • D. enzyme 4 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate N to product O
  • E. enzyme 5 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate O to product P
Check Answer
